text: you might not peg lawrence carter-long
for a dancer at least until you see him
step into this rehearsal space on West
47th Street in Manhattan
lawrence who has cerebral palsy belongs
to a dance company called even the
name is a confrontation of certain
notions of disability and dance
disability in our culture is allowed to
be inspirational
we're allowed to be heroic or sometimes
allowed to be pathetic what we're not
allowed to be creative the troupe is
preparing for an upcoming performance
which includes another not so PC element
a sequence in which Lawrence gets
manhandled by the muscular dancer
Jeffrey freeze this is no you know safe
prearranged marriage of dance and
disability this is a collision this is
two worlds coming together that ain't
supposed to coexist and check out
Lawrence's opening lines he goes on to
mimic what people say to him and the
others after seeing them dance
the goal is to honor each person's
really specific ways of moving really
specific unique personalities the
company was founded by the dancer and
choreographer Heidi Lansky who rather
than work around their particular
limitations tries to find unique
abilities in these dancers bodies and
explore their artistic possibilities and
make what I call a movement portrait
something a dance that kind of speaks to
who they are to their to their
vulnerability to their strengths to
their uniqueness to their personalities
like Lawrence who is a really specific
gait I can't change his gait there's so
much rhythm to his gait that's so
interesting there's so much movement and
almost music within his gait that it's
just added something that I could never
even attempt to to move in that way that
he just does naturally then there is
Catherine long an artist from London who
was born with no hip sockets no kneecaps
and no left arm when I put myself out
there on stage I want I'm inviting
people to look at me and I'm controlling
the looking
whereas when I'm in the street I'm not
inviting people to look at me but they
do anyway so this puts me in a bit more
of a controlled situation where I might
then be trying to encourage people to
also look at themselves and look at the
way that they look at different bodies
and their own body they don't really
know how to respond they don't know what
to say but I think they're so surprised
that they they often sort of seem to
need a bit of time to process it and for
them their brains to adjust to what
they've just seen and been part of as an
audience
really challenges a lot of people's
ideas about what a dancer is
